items.title: Nifty caught in tug-of-war, follow-through buying crucial this week
items.description: Nifty shows potential recovery with bullish candlestick patterns, but buying momentum is necessary. Open interest declines and FPIs shift to bearish positions, indicating cautious trading ahead.

items.title: Ahead of Market: 10 things that will decide stock action on Monday
items.description: Indian equity indices Sensex and Nifty50 ended a three-day losing streak, driven by Axis Bank gains, despite foreign fund outflows causing a third consecutive weekly loss for benchmarks.

items.title: 8 Indian stocks that align with Peter Lynch's growth investing approach
items.description: American investor and mutual fund manager Peter Lynch is renowned for his growth at a reasonable price approach to investing. He is often associated with the PEG ratio, which measures price-to-earnings ratios in relation to growth rates. MarketSmith has developed a custom screen based on Lynch's investment style, identifying securities that trade at below-average prices on a PE or PEG basis and are not widely owned by institutions.Here are 8 Indian stocks that align with Peter Lynch's growth investing approach, as listed on MarketSmith:

items.title: This ratio help in better long-term investing: 4 large-caps and 1 small-cap stock with the right PEG ratio
items.description: How do you value a stock? Which has a high valuation, and which is cheap? It all depends on the ratio you use to ascertain value. And relying entirely on the price to earnings (PE) ratio may lead to wrong investment decisions. Consider this example: Twelve years back, the stock of one MNC FMCG company was quoting at a PE multiple of 44 at a time the Nifty’s PE was at 25. Since then, the market capitalization of the stock has grown 10 times and its PE ratio today stands at 68. So, if you had made a decision to buy or sell the stock based on its PE number, you would have lost a great opportunity to create wealth. So, look beyond the PE ratio.

items.title: Diwali Muhurat trading on November 1. NSE, BSE announce timing, other details
items.description: The NSE will host its Diwali Muhurat trading on November 1, 2024, from 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM, symbolizing the financial new year and traditionally yielding positive returns.

items.title: ​Breakout Stocks: How to trade HDFC Bank and Tech Mahindra post Q2 results?
items.description: Indian market recouped losses to close in the green on Friday. The S&P BSE Sensex rose more than 200 points while the Nifty50 closed above 24,800 levels.

items.title: Mcap of 4 of top-10 most valued firms jumps Rs 81,151 cr last week; ICICI, HDFC Bank biggest gainers
items.description: While HDFC Bank, Bharti Airtel, ICICI Bank, and the State Bank of India were the gainers, Reliance Industries, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), Infosys, Hindustan Unilever, ITC, and Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC) suffered a combined erosion of Rs 76,622.05 crore from their market valuation.

items.title: ​Nestle India, Gujarat Gas among 5 stocks with short buildup
items.description: A short buildup occurs when there is a rise in open interest and trading volumes, coupled with a decrease in the price of the underlying stock in the Futures and Options segment. This indicates that more traders are expecting the prices to decline and are creating short positions. In Friday's trading session, five stocks saw fresh short positions being built. Here's the list:

items.title: Market Trading Guide: Paradeep Phosphates, 1 more smallcap are stock recommendations for Monday
items.description: Indian indices rebounded as private banks led a recovery, breaking a three-session losing streak. Experts suggest buying Paradeep Phosphates and Vishnu Prakash R Punglia for potential gains.

items.title: ​Diwali picks: Top 5 stocks with up to 105% upside potential in Samvat 2081
items.description: Indian indices are currently valued highly compared to their historical averages, and many stocks across various sectors have low margins of safety at their current prices. Although currently undergoing a correction, the broader trend of the markets remains positive. To mark the beginning of a new 'samvat', domestic brokerage firm Wellworth Share & Stock Broking shares top 5 Diwali picks with up to 105% upside potential:

items.title: Canara Bank, Tata Communications among 5 stocks with long buildup
items.description: A long buildup occurs when open interest and trading volumes increase alongside a rise in the underlying stock price in the Futures and Options segment, signaling a bullish market trend. In Friday's trading session, five stocks saw fresh long positions. Here’s the list:

items.title: Hyundai listing, Q2 results among 8 factors to drive stock market this week
items.description: Nifty declined 0.44% this week, influenced by auto, metal, and IT stocks. Key upcoming factors include FII flows, IPO activity, Q2 results, and global market trends

items.title: These 8 penny stocks surge 15-30% in a week
items.description: In the week ending October 18, the benchmark index Sensex, experienced a weekly decline of about 0.19%. Despite this slight downturn in the markets, 8 penny stocks saw gains ranging from 15% to 30% during the same timeframe. Our selection criteria focused on stocks with a market capitalization below Rs 1000 crore, a share price under Rs 20, and a last trading volume exceeding 5 lakh shares.(Data Source: ACE Equity)

items.title: For risk-takers with medium-term perspective: 6 mid-cap stocks from different sectors with upside potential of up to 47%
items.description: Contradictions are part of the market – and it is important to know how to manage them. What are the contradictions in the markets today? The one between the desire to buy and the high valuations on the one hand, and the fear of correction on the other. The contradiction between the desire to buy and high valuations is not new. The fear of correction set in at the start of this month with the strong wave of FPI selling. What should investors do? The answer: Go back to basics. Have more checks and balances; invest with a medium- to long-term perspective so that you don’t end up selling in panic in a corrective phase. And remember, it’s a phase we may have to live with for the next few months.

items.title: All weather investing: Protecting your portfolio from market downturns
items.description: Many overlook that a portfolio can still perform well during downturns if its drawdown is smaller than that of the broader market. In today’s unpredictable financial landscape, effectively managing various risks is essential for creating a resilient, all-weather portfolio. In this article, we will explore strategies for building such a portfolio.

items.title: Sector rotation in focus: Where to find opportunities in a sideways market
items.description: The Nifty is currently range-bound, with key support at 24500-24650 and resistance at 25000-25100.  A break below support could lead to further weakness, while a move above resistance might signal a renewed uptrend. Sector rotation is expected, with opportunities in financials, energy, and consumption. Investors should remain cautious and selective in their stock picks.
